channel.title: Science : NPR
channel.description: The latest health and science news. Updates on medicine, healthy living, nutrition, drugs, diet, and advances in science and technology. Subscribe to the Health & Science podcast.

item.title: Photographer Builds A 'Photo Ark' For 6,500 Animal Species And Counting
item.description: February 27, 2017 - National Geographic photographer Joel Sartore is on a mission to document every captive animal species in the world. He talks about getting an arctic fox to hold still, and Photoshopping out poop.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 27, 2017 - National Geographic photographer Joel Sartore is on a mission to document every captive animal species in the world. He talks about getting an arctic fox to hold still, and Photoshopping out poop. http://www.npr.org/2017/02/27/517481473/photographer-builds-a-photo-ark-for-6-500-animal-species-and-counting

item.title: Your Name Might Shape Your Face, Researchers Say
item.description: February 27, 2017 - Do you look like a Joy? Genes and culture may make it more likely that names and faces align. But researchers say people also may adjust their expressions to match social expectations of their name.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 27, 2017 - Do you look like a Joy? Genes and culture may make it more likely that names and faces align. But researchers say people also may adjust their expressions to match social expectations of their name. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/02/27/517496915/your-name-might-shape-your-face-researchers-say

item.title: A Medicine That Blunts The Buzz Of Alcohol Can Help Drinkers Cut Back
item.description: February 27, 2017 - Naltrexone was approved to treat alcohol disorders more than 20 years ago. But many doctors still don't know that when combined with counseling it can help people resist the urge to drink too much.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 27, 2017 - Naltrexone was approved to treat alcohol disorders more than 20 years ago. But many doctors still don't know that when combined with counseling it can help people resist the urge to drink too much. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/02/27/516890375/a-medicine-that-blunts-the-buzz-of-alcohol-can-help-drinkers-cut-back

item.title: Fearing Climate Change Policy Under Trump, STEM Group Works To Get Scientists Elected
item.description: February 26, 2017 - Scientists across the country are planning to go to Washington — and take office. Shaughnessy Naughton is the founder of 314 Action a non profit that helps scientists run for office.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 26, 2017 - Scientists across the country are planning to go to Washington — and take office. Shaughnessy Naughton is the founder of 314 Action a non profit that helps scientists run for office. http://www.npr.org/2017/02/26/517394115/fearing-climate-change-policy-under-trump-stem-group-is-working-to-get-scientist

item.title: Astronomers Find 7 Potentially Habitable Planets
item.description: February 26, 2017 - Astronomers have discovered a solar system full of potentially habitable planets. Lulu Garcia-Navarro talks to Seth Shostak of the SETI Institute, which searches for extraterrestrial intelligence.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 26, 2017 - Astronomers have discovered a solar system full of potentially habitable planets. Lulu Garcia-Navarro talks to Seth Shostak of the SETI Institute, which searches for extraterrestrial intelligence. http://www.npr.org/2017/02/26/517305291/astronomers-find-7-potentially-habitable-planets

item.title: Why It's Been So Warm On The East Coast
item.description: February 26, 2017 - The east coast saw record-breaking high temperatures this past week. Meteorologist Bob Henson talks with NPR's Lulu Garcia-Navarro about what's behind the early spring weather.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 26, 2017 - The east coast saw record-breaking high temperatures this past week. Meteorologist Bob Henson talks with NPR's Lulu Garcia-Navarro about what's behind the early spring weather. http://www.npr.org/2017/02/26/517305249/why-its-been-so-warm-on-the-east-coast

item.title: Dentists Work To Ease Patients' Pain With Fewer Opioids
item.description: February 26, 2017 - After minor surgeries, many dentists used to reflexively prescribe quick-acting opioids to relieve a patient's pain. Now they're learning to counsel patients about better, less addictive alternatives.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 26, 2017 - After minor surgeries, many dentists used to reflexively prescribe quick-acting opioids to relieve a patient's pain. Now they're learning to counsel patients about better, less addictive alternatives. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/02/26/513865623/dentists-work-to-ease-patients-pain-with-fewer-opioids

item.title: Explaining The Sizzling Sound Of Meteors
item.description: February 25, 2017 - Scientists recently published a paper explaining why some meteors create strange sounds. NPR's Scott Simon talks with researcher Bill Sweatt about what creates this "sizzling" sound.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 25, 2017 - Scientists recently published a paper explaining why some meteors create strange sounds. NPR's Scott Simon talks with researcher Bill Sweatt about what creates this "sizzling" sound. http://www.npr.org/2017/02/25/517181421/explaining-the-sizzling-sound-of-meteors

item.title: A Taste For Pork Helped A Deadly Virus Jump To Humans
item.description: February 25, 2017 - People were dropping dead in Malaysia, and no one could figure out why their brains were swelling. A young scientist solved the mystery. Then he had to get people to believe him.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 25, 2017 - People were dropping dead in Malaysia, and no one could figure out why their brains were swelling. A young scientist solved the mystery. Then he had to get people to believe him. http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/02/25/515258818/a-taste-for-pork-helped-a-deadly-virus-jump-to-humans

item.title: When You Love An Old Dog, Managing Care Can Be A Challenge
item.description: February 25, 2017 - Aging dogs often need extra medical care. But there comes a time to be realistic about what can and can't be done, veterinarians say. The pet's comfort is paramount.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 25, 2017 - Aging dogs often need extra medical care. But there comes a time to be realistic about what can and can't be done, veterinarians say. The pet's comfort is paramount. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/02/25/515610795/when-you-love-an-old-dog-managing-care-can-be-a-challenge

item.title: VX: The Nerve Agent Used To Kill Kim Jong Nam Is Rare And Deadly
item.description: February 24, 2017 - A colorless, odorless liquid, similar in consistency to motor oil, VX kills in tiny quantities that can be absorbed through the skin. It is among the deadliest chemical weapons ever devised.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 24, 2017 - A colorless, odorless liquid, similar in consistency to motor oil, VX kills in tiny quantities that can be absorbed through the skin. It is among the deadliest chemical weapons ever devised. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/02/24/517053496/vx-the-nerve-agent-used-to-kill-kim-jong-nam-is-rare-and-deadly

item.title: Advice From Patients On A Study's Design Makes For Better Science
item.description: February 24, 2017 - Increasingly, advocates for patients are in the room when big medical studies are designed. They demand answers to big questions: "Will the results of this study actually help anybody?"
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 24, 2017 - Increasingly, advocates for patients are in the room when big medical studies are designed. They demand answers to big questions: "Will the results of this study actually help anybody?" http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/02/24/515226648/advice-from-patients-on-a-studys-design-makes-for-better-science

item.title: Mildred Dresselhaus, 'Queen Of Carbon' And Nanoscience Trailblazer, Dies At 86
item.description: February 24, 2017 - The daughter of poor immigrants, Dresselhaus became science royalty for her work with carbon materials. Along the way she opened opportunities for female scientists that didn't exist when she started.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 24, 2017 - The daughter of poor immigrants, Dresselhaus became science royalty for her work with carbon materials. Along the way she opened opportunities for female scientists that didn't exist when she started. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/02/24/517004254/mildred-dresselhaus-queen-of-carbon-and-nanoscience-trailblazer-dies-at-86

item.title: Eric Haseltine: Can The Past Guide Us To Future Scientific Breakthroughs?
item.description: February 24, 2017 - Trained as a neuroscientist, Eric Haseltine always asks questions. He's identified four concepts that lead to scientific breakthrough. One of them: acknowledging we're not the center of the universe.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 24, 2017 - Trained as a neuroscientist, Eric Haseltine always asks questions. He's identified four concepts that lead to scientific breakthrough. One of them: acknowledging we're not the center of the universe. http://www.npr.org/2017/02/24/516727050/eric-haseltine-can-the-past-guide-us-to-future-scientific-breakthroughs

item.title: Liz Coleman: How Do We Teach College Students To Ask Big Questions?
item.description: February 24, 2017 - Former Bennington College President Liz Coleman believes higher education is overly-specialized & complacent. She says we need to encourage students to ask bigger questions and take more risks.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 24, 2017 - Former Bennington College President Liz Coleman believes higher education is overly-specialized & complacent. She says we need to encourage students to ask bigger questions and take more risks. http://www.npr.org/2017/02/24/516726045/liz-coleman-how-do-we-teach-college-students-to-ask-big-questions
